a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sin_cos :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "sin_cos = (\<lambda> x y. sin x * cos y + sin y * cos x)"
shows  "sin_cos 70 50 + sin_cos 260 280 = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify
\[\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We have that $\sin 70^\circ = \cos 20^\circ,$ $\sin 260^\circ = -\sin 80^\circ = -\cos 10^\circ,$ and $\cos 280^\circ = \cos 80^\circ = \sin 10^\circ,$ so \[\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ = \cos 20^\circ \cos 50^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ.\]Then by product-to-sum, \begin{align}
 \cos 20^\circ \cos 50^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 70^\circ + \cos 30^\circ) - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \cos 70^\circ + \frac{1}{2} \cos 30^\circ - \frac{1}{2} \sin 20^\circ \\
 &= \frac{1}{2} \cos 30^\circ = \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}}. \end{align}
 *)
